dc:description:
Spermatogenic Failure 19 is a form of male infertility caused by multiple morphologic abnormalities of the sperm flagella (MMAF) that impair sperm motility (PMID: 28552195). Individuals with Spermatogenic Failure 19 present with a combination of sperm flagellar malformations (absent, short, coiled, bent, and/or irregular-caliber flagella), unassembled sperm fibrous sheaths, and defects in axoneme structure (a lack of or misalignment of the central pair microtubules, disorganized double microtubules) (PMIDs: 31781811, 31210147).

Mutations were first reported in the *CFAP43* (*Cilia-and Flagella-Associated Protein 43*) gene in association with Spermatogenic Failure 19 in 2017 by Tang et al. (PMID: 28552195). Whole exome sequencing was used to identify biallelic *CFAP43* mutations in men with MMAF. The specific disease entity, Spermatogenic Failure 19, is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by homozygous or compound heterozygous mutation in the *CFAP43* gene. Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we found the molecular mechanism and autosomal recessive mode of inheritance to be consistent among unrelated patients, while the phenotypic variability among them appeared to represent a spectrum of disease rather than separate disease entities. Therefore, cases of primary male infertility caused by inherited *CFAP43* variants have been lumped into a single disease entity, Spermatogenic Failure 19 (MONDO: 0054723, OMIM: 617592).

Evidence from 15 probands in 3 publications has been included in this curation representing 16 unique *CFAP43* variants (3 missense, 5 nonsense, 6 frameshift, 2 splice site, and 1 large deletion). The mechanism of pathogenicity in *CFAP43* mutations appears to be biallelic loss of function. There is additional case-level evidence available in the literature, but its inclusion in this curation was not necessary to reach the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 points).

The gene-disease association between *CFAP43* and Spermatogenic Failure 19 is supported by gene expression and protein localization studies. RNAseq studies in humans (PMID: 24309898) show a high level of *CFAP43* expression in testis.  Murine RNAseq studies during sperm development show a pattern of increasing *CFAP43* expression during the progression of spermatogenesis (PMID: 31781811). Immunoelectron and stimulated-emission-depletion microscopy performed on TbCFAP43 and TbCFAP44 in the flagellated protozoan *Trypanosoma brucei* show that both proteins are located between the doublet microtubules 5 and 6 (DMT 5-6) and the paraflagellar rod (PMID: 3319078). The paraflagellar rod runs parallel to the axoneme along most of its length and is connected to axoneme doublet microtubules 4-7. The DMT 5-6 bridge limits inter-doublet sliding, offering a firm plane that is vertical to the bending plane of the flagella. Were CFAP43 to also be localized to the DMT 5-6 bridge in humans (as has been shown in *T. brucei*), the absence of CFAP43 in human patients could destabilize this complex, producing both peri-axonemal and axonemal defects that are consistent with the defective sperm phenotypes seen in patients with Spermatogenic Failure 19.

Two animal models have been used to support the gene-disease relationship between *CFAP43* and Spermatogenic Failure 19. Frameshift mutations in the mouse *CFAP43* ortholog, *Cfap43*, were induced by CRISPR/Cas9 technology. *Cfap43*-deficient male mice, like human male patients with biallelic mutation in *CFAP43*, exhibited male infertility and reduced or no sperm motility (PMID: 28552195). Almost all spermatozoa of *Cfap43*-deficient male mice had flagellar abnormalities. These flagella had short, coiled, or other distorted shapes, consistent with the clinical phenotypes seen in human patients with MMAF. In addition, these mice showed ultrastructural defects consistent with those seen in human patients: disorganized axoneme, no central pair complex (CPC), disarranged outer dense fibers and peripheral microtubules. *Trypanosoma brucei* was used as a model organism to characterize the role of TbCFAP43 in the structure and beating of the trypanosome flagellum (PMID: 29449551). Inducible RNA interference knockdown of *TbCFAP43* in *T. brucei*  produced cells with abnormal flagellar beating, multi-flagellated cells, a reduction in cell proliferation, and severe ultrastructural defects: disorganized axoneme ultrastructure, 90° rotated CPC, displaced CPC and DMTs, and abnormally enlarged flagellar pocket with multiple flagella. The ultrastructural defects and abnormal flagellar beating seen in trypanosome *TbCFAP43* knockdown are consistent with the abnormal sperm motility, abnormal sperm axoneme morphology, and central pair defects seen in patients with *CFAP43* mutations and suggest that CFAP43 is required for axonemal organization in sperm flagella.

*Cfap43*-deficient mice were used to demonstrate that Cfap43 plays an important role in intra-manchette transport (IMT) during spermeogenesis (PMID: 33046149). Intra-manchette transport (IMT) transfers structural and functional proteins via microtubule tracks and motor proteins to the basal body region. The manchette is essential for the shaping of the sperm head and formation of the sperm tail. A role for CFAP43 in intra-manchette transport is consistent with the defects seen in sperm morphology and motility in *CFAP43* patients.

In summary, there is **definitive** evidence supporting a gene-disease relationship between variants in *CFAP43* and Spermatogenic Failure 19. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Motile Ciliopathy GCEP on October 13, 2022 (SOP Version 9).

evidence.dc:description: NM_025145.7(CFAP43):c.2802T>A (p.Cys934Ter) is a nonsense mutation that is predicted to trigger NMD or at least truncate ~44% of the protein product.
NM_025145.7(CFAP43):c.4132C>T (p.Arg1378Ter) is a nonsense mutation that is predicted to trigger NMD or at least truncate ~17% of the protein product.

evidence.rdfs:label: Tang_P003
evidence.detectionMethod: Candidate pathogenic mutations and their parental origins were verified by Sanger sequencing.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Multiple Morphological Abnormalities of the Flagella (MMAF)

evidence.dc:description: NM_025145.7(CFAP43):c.1240_1241del (p.Val414LeufsTer46) is a frameshift mutation that replaces Val 414 with Leu and an early termination signal 46 amino acids downstream.  This alteration is predicted to lead to NMD or a 75% truncated protein. The default score of 1.5 has been downscored to 1 because of homozygosity. This variant is also present in patient Coutton_P04.

evidence.rdfs:label: Coutton_P3
evidence.detectionMethod: Identified mutations were validated by Sanger sequencing.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Multiple Morphological Abnormalities of the Flagella (MMAF)

evidence.dc:description: NM_025145.7(CFAP43):c.1040T>C (p.Val347Ala) is a missense mutation with possibly damaging consequences according to PolyPhen, low allele frequency in gnomAD, and in a conserved residue within one of CFAP43's WDR domains.

NM_025145.7(CFAP43):c.1302dup (p.Leu435fs) is a frameshift mutation that replaces Leu 435 with a Ser and a premature terminations signal 26 amino acids downstream. This alteration is predicted to trigger NMD or produce a 74% truncated protein.

evidence.detectionMethod: Identified mutations were validated by Sanger sequencing.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Multiple Morphological Abnormalities of the Flagella (MMAF)

evidence.dc:description: NM_025145.7(CFAP43):c.253C>T (p.Arg85Trp) is a missense mutation predicted to replace a highly conserved Arg 85 with Trp.  The mutation has no experimental evidence of gene impact but is present at low allele frequency in gnomAD and is predicted to be probably damaging by Polyphen and deleterious by SIFT.

NM_025145.7(CFAP43):c.3945-263_4431+252del is a 3.3-kb deletion within CFAP43 that eliminates exons 32–34 and is predicted to cause a frameshift in CFAP43 that replaces Ile 1316 with Leu and a termination signal 10 amino acids downstream. It is predicted to trigger NMD or at least truncate ~21% of the protein product.

evidence.rdfs:label: Tang_P028
evidence.detectionMethod: Candidate pathogenic mutations and their parental origins were verified by Sanger sequencing. One variant in this individual was identified as a 3.3-kb heterozygous deletion within CFAP43 by using a Comparative Genomic Hybridization (CGH) and long-range PCR assay.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Multiple Morphological Abnormalities of the Flagella (MMAF)

evidence.dc:description: NM_025145.7(CFAP43):c.2658G>A (p.Trp886Ter) is a nonsense mutation predicted to trigger NMD or produce a 47% truncated protein. The default score of 1.5 has been downscored to 1 because of homozygosity.

evidence.detectionMethod: Identified mutations were validated by Sanger sequencing.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Multiple Morphological Abnormalities of the Flagella (MMAF)

evidence.dc:description: NM_025145.7(CFAP43):c.3541-2A>C is a mutation in the consensus splice acceptor site of CFAP43 intron 27. It is predicted to replace Ser 1181 with Lys and a premature termination signal 4 amino acids downstream, either triggering NMD or producing a 29% truncated protein.  However, no experimental mRNA evidence is presented to provide proof of this mutation's effect on splicing.  This variant is also present in patient  Coutton_P02.

evidence.dc:description: This variant has been downscored to 1 because of homozygosity (-0.5) and consanguinity (-0.5)

To determine the effects of the frameshift mutation (c.1577_1578del) on CFAP43 expression, authors measured CFAP43 mRNA in spermatozoa of the patient using the sperm sample from a fertile male as control. As shown in Figure 3c, CFAP43 mRNA was detected in the control sample, but not in the patient Khan Family 2 IV-3, suggesting that this variant CFAP43 transcript undergoes NMD.

NC_000010.11:g.104185011C>T (GRCh38) is a splicing mutation that is predicted to alter the consensus splice donor site of CFAP43 exon 16. One predicted outcome of this mutation would be a frameshift mutation that replaces Lys 714 with Val and a premature termination signal 11 amino acids downstream.  This could trigger NMD or produce a 57% truncated protein. There is, however, no experimental mRNA evidence to substantiate these claims.

evidence.detectionMethod: Identified mutations were validated by Sanger sequencing.

evidence.dc:description: NM_025145.7(CFAP43):c.3352C>T (p.Arg1118Ter) is a nonsense mutation predicted to trigger NMD or produce a 33% truncated protein. The default score of 1.5 has been downscored to 1 because of homozygosity.

TEM analysis of sperm cells from this patient show severe axonemal disorganization, including  short tails, disorganized components of the flagella,  misplaced or rotated CP, extra DMT and absence of CP. Immunofluorescent studies of sperm cells with SPAG6 (located in CPC) and RSPH1 (radial spoke head protein) confirmed abnormal patterns of axoneme organization.  Staining with AKAP4, DNAL1, DNAI2, GAS8 were all normal suggesting that the FS, ODAs, IDAs, and next-dynein regulatory complex, respectively were not affected .  These data will be scored in experimental section of curation.

evidence.dc:description: Cfap43-deficient male mice, like human male patients with biallelic mutation in CFAP43 exhibited male infertility and reduced or no sperm motility. Almost all spermatozoa of Cfap43-deficient male mice had flagellar abnormalities. These flagella presented with short, coiled, or other distorted shapes, consistent with the clinical phenotypes in humans subjects with MMAF.
evidence.rdfs:label: CFAP43-Deficient Mouse Model

evidence.dc:description: Mutations in CFAP43 cause male infertility associated with sperm axonemal central pair defects. The main defect based on human sperm EM cross sections appears to be the lack of central pair, although some completely disorganized axonemal and accessory structures are also observed.  In some CFAP43 mutation patients, the missing central pair was accompanied by disorganized outer doublets. In other patients the central pair was mis-oriented when present. In the Trypanosome ciliate, TbCFAP43 is localized on the outer surface of the doublet microtubules. Based on this observation, humans CFAP43 is suggested to have a role in connecting specific doublet microtubules to periaxonemal structures in the human sperm tail. Ultrastructural defects and abnormal flagella beating seen in Trypanosome TbCFAP43 knockdown is consistent with abnormal sperm motility, abnormal sperm axoneme morphology, and central pair defects seen in patients with CFAP43 mutations.
evidence.rdfs:label: T. Brucei CFAP43 ortholog required for axonemal organization

evidence.dc:description: Spermatogenic failure 19 is associated with primary male infertility and with MMAF (Multiple Morphological Abnormalities of the Flagella).  This mouse model suggests that a loss of CFAP43 leads to abnormal spermiogenesis.  The abnormal assembly of manchette microtubles in the absence of CFAP43 interferes with normal formation of the sperm tail and shaping of the head.
evidence.rdfs:label: Murine Cfap43-mediated intra-manchette transport

evidence.dc:description: Trypanosoma brucei, a flagellated protozoan, was used as a model organism to help characterize the possible role of human CFAP43 in the structure of the sperm flagellum.  Immunoelectron and stimulated-emission depletion microscopy performed on epitope-tagged (Myc or TY1) TbCFAP43 shows that in Trypanosome, the CFAP43 ortholog localizes between the axonemal double microtubules 5 and 6 and the paraflagellar rod. The 5–6 bridge is a doublet-specific structure that links DMTs 5 and 6 in the axonemes of many animal cilia and flagella (PMID:31210147)  This bridge limits the inter-doublet sliding against its neighbor, offering a firm plane that is vertical to the bending plane of the flagella. The absence of CFAP43 could destabilize this complex, producing both peri-axonemal and axonemal defects.
evidence.rdfs:label: TbCFAP43 localizes to DMTs 5/6 and paraflagellar rod

evidence.dc:description: RNAseq of human tissue samples detects high RPKM (Reads Per Kilobase Million) value of 50 for CFAP43 in human testis.
evidence.rdfs:label: CFAP43 gene highly expressed in human testis

evidence.dc:description: RNAseq was conducted on mouse testis tissue collected at specific postnatal time points.  The murine CFAP43 ortholog showed a pattern of increasing expression during the progression of spermatogenesis reaching a high level expression (98 FPKM, Fragments Per Kilobase Million) by PND (Post Natal Day) 28.
evidence.rdfs:label: Murine CFAP43 ortholog expressed during spermatogenesis
